Nice little coffee shop nook in Bernal.  I needed a space to kick it with my laptop and finish some work on a Saturday afternoon and Cafe St. Jorge was perfect. I ordered the Goose is Loose (grilled ham and cheese with banana) and an almond milk cocoa smoothie that I forget the name of. The sandwich was delicious (banana, cheese and ham actually do work!) and came with a pretty mixed green salad. I also finished the smoothie in about 30 seconds after getting it delivered to my table.

WiFi is free and there were plenty of free seats, I'll definitely be back!
author: Melissah L.

description: Great food, casual comfortable atmosphere and very positive service. Try the cappuccino with homemade biscotti or the egg bake slider, is also amazing the only thing better than the food was the service.
author: Mick F.

description: Great cafe with yummy food, but service not so good. They are very slow and often forget your order. There is also too many laptops!
author: Penny S.

description:
Best. Vegan Cookie. Ever. HOLY WOW!!! The Famous Chocolate Chip cookie is to die for. Great coffee, too. 

One note: I felt a bit self conscious walking the walk through the cafe from door to register.... as all of the people seated at the tables are on either side of you, and if they look up as you pass, it feels a bit like the catwalk. 

So I would say to you this: Dress to impress! You are going for That Cookie. Go for it, you got this. It is completely worth it. And Get. That. Cookie.

A+++++++++++++ 

Thanks, and keep it up Cafe St. George!!
author: D M.

description: Great place, okay food. There's plenty of okay food in the city, and while Cafe St. Jorge is cute, it doesn't elevate anything else to the point where I'd make my way back here unless it's on the way.
author: Victoria C.

description:
Started coming here with my room mates for breakfast since we live close. I have been consuming chia pudding for years but man is there's be best I've ever had. Of course I'm sure they sweeten it which I do not buy those coconut shreds are to die for and i don't mind indulging once a week! Not a fan of their espresso, it's really sour but this is also coming from someone who is not supposed to consume coffee. 

I love their tea selection. It hits the spot on a cold San Francisco morning. I also love their fruit bowl!! I like to keep it simple. Customer service varies. It's usually good but at times I don't like the way they look at me. I get it you guys are busy and you can't be happy all the time!
author: Emmy M.

description:
I would totally give this place a 5 if it weren't for the crappy attitude of the cashier/barista. Minus the attitude this place is really good! 
I ordered a little bit of everything, the chili avocado toast, the gluten free egg sammie, granola and yogurt. All were good!
author: Natasha I.

description:
This place is one of my favorite spots to get some work done while grabbing a quick breakfast! I usually get the avocado toast because who doesn't love bread and avocado? And the hint of spiciness with the chili flakes is nice, and they're not stingy with the avocado. The coffee is amazing too, as are the selection of coffee additives (raw sugar, brown sugar, simple syrup, cardamom, chocolate powder, cinnamon)--you can basically make your own custom latte. 

The smoothies are overpriced and kind of gross though. I stopped by for the berry chia smoothie once, and it'll be my last. Its pretty small and had the consistency of juice, and was ridiculously priced ($9!). I have no idea what I was thinking when I ordered it.
author: Trena M.

description:
This adorable cafe, which serves pastries & a couple of breakfast items with a Portuguese flair, was perfect for a leisurely first meal with my girl. I could see myself coming back, laptop in tow, & clicking my day away. 

We sampled a variety of items, as we usually do (how else are you gonna know if a spot is worth a second try?!):

-- orange blossom waffle: couldn't taste a hint of citrus, sufficiently sweet & had a texture like buckwheat. Real maple syrup. 
-- baked egg breakfast slider: too tiny, if it's the only thing you're eating; just right, if it's just one of many items you're sampling. Sweet Portuguese bread was a nice contrast from savory eggs & cheese. 
-- quinoa bowl: with almond milk & fruits. Very healthy tasting, definitely a little fancier than the oatmeal I make at home!

Would absolutely come back to try their special toasts, one made with avocado & chili, the other with cinnamon sugar.
author: Fancypants X.

description: Trust is a two-way street. I trust St. Jorge with the ham, Portucheese, & banana grilled "trust us" sando. St. Jorge learned #thehardway #sharonjonesandthedapkings to trust me with the orange waffle covered in ham, avocado, and syzzurp. Plus cred for The Life Jorquatic With Saint Zissjorge bonheur de vivre everywhere. Minus for all the workers' beanies being non-red; the get-up-and-risk-your-table-and-pay-as-you-go ordering format; also for so easily funnyfacing and being outstranged by my diy dish. #eatweird #gogrossorgohome Aaaaalmost 4 stars.
author: Dan B.

description: It's a lovely place. Awesome food, great atmosphere. I had the waffle with fruits yogurt and granola. It was really good.  I will definitely come again.
author: Jürgen H.

description: I got the vanilla latte here and it was delicious! I usually get a caramel latte/macchiato when I go to other places, but since they have the original macchiatos I opted for a vanilla latte. It was not overly sweet and still had the coffee taste to it. The atmosphere here is also very relaxing. I would definitely come here to study or just do some work on my laptop. Everyone working here is really nice and friendly as well.
author: Diamond N.

description:
I almost did not want to write a review because I don't want this place to get too popular!
but it's just fair. 

Note: Seating has signs (don't pick your chairs before ordering, 60 minutes time maximum; no laptops during certain hours)

- Great customer service, casual, friendly, attentive
- Excellent food (I ordered a sandwich with egg and the avocado spread)
- Strong coffee, but very very good. I love strong dark coffee and they have it! 

It gets busy early on 8:30am and on... 


Love this spot cafe!
author: Sara J.

description: I love this cozy cafe! Great food + a really wonderful place to hang out to read/work. Friendly + sunny. Plus they have some healthy alternatives that are very yummy!
author: Sherry B.

description:
During my pregnancy last year, my goal was to visit lots of cafes near St. Luke's.  I wanted to check this place out because I saw that they serve Srsly sourdough gluten free bread that I've been meaning to try.  It's a cute little area.  I've tried their latte (yum) and toast on the gf bread.  They ask you if need your bread toasted in a separate toaster to avoid cross contamination.  
Service is a hit or miss though.  But I do like the ambiance and the food.  I'd love to come back and try their pastries.
author: Claire J.

description: Wow what a great aesthetic! I came here in pursuit of the Cocoa Almond Bliss, after seeing it on a summer coffee list Walking in, I loved what this place was all about. Loved the barista that helped me out, and I think this would be a fantastic local joint. I don't think it gets more local/slightly pretentious but they are worth it. The only reason they aren't 5 stars for me is that this drink ended up costing $9 with a shot of espresso, which I wasn't expecting. It's my own fault for pursuing a drink and not checking the menu, but it was an unpleasant shock. Smooth drink though I can't lie.
author: Sophia B.

description:
Found this place with a friend walking by
And it's fantastic!!!!!
Love the ginger juice so healthy!!!!
Great toast!!
author: Alessandro B.

description: I was excited to try to avocado toast but the bread came out cold and stale; my knife couldn't even cut into it. Then I realized the whole bread was burnt. I ended up just scraping off the avocado. Paid around $10 for avocado and hot chocolate. At least the hot chocolate had latte art for a cute photo.
author: Kimmy L.

description:
Cafe St. Jorge has the nicest, most edible, most original cafe menu in the city. Everything is real honest food, not gross gut bombs or the generic cafe fair of old quiche and bagels. I'm picky- I don't want big gross carb fests but I also don't want rabbit food. Think fava bean purée on sliced baguettes with fresh lemon, olive oil, sea salt and tuna (or was it sardines? I dunno but it was filling and delicious), big chia bowls with dried fruit, nuts and fresh strawberries and bananas, almond smoothies with dates and cocoa, waffles, fresh juices with ginger and other yummy flavors, Portuguese style snack plates, fig toast with ricotta and honey, avocado toasts, etc. 

The staff is genuinely friendly and intelligent, the iced tea has me going for hours, good lighting, newspapers, and magazines!
author: Francesca S.

description: Small coffee shops that can make you a quick and delicious cup of coffee, they also have a few small food items if you want something to eat.
author: Scott N.

description: Vegan snack heaaaven ((I recommend the almond-butter chocolate cup)) this place is bright and breezy and has soft music- good for studying if you don't like loudness or total silence. A great place for vegans and non-vegans alike :)
author: Emma M.

description: The avo toast was a tad too acidic for my taste but I did enjoy my macchiato. It was very strong, creamy, and not sour.
author: Heejin L.

description: Very happy to have read other yelp reviews and stopped here. Friendly service, clean, nice ambience, really good coffee and delicious sandwiches, salads and snacks. We enjoyed quinoa salad, Portuguese cheese/ham and breakfast sandwiches, banana bread. No laptops permitted 9 am to 2 pm.
author: Leann C.

description:
Lovely ambiance and versatile menu that keeps both vegans and meat eaters happy!  I'm so glad to find a place that offers something besides the usual worn-out options.  Cafe St. Jorge's menu items are fresh and ever-changing ... simple foods, only put together in expected and delightful combinations.  

The vegan menu items I've tried::

* hot quinoa bowl with steamed almond milk, walnuts, strawberries, blueberries and cinnamon (loved it!) 
* cold chia bowl: soaked chia, housemade almond milk, cinnamon, fresh & dried fruit, nuts, seeds, agave, dates (delicious!)
* gigantic Texas toast and topped with the best avocados and chili flakes money can buy (yum!)
* vegan donuts which appeared to be from Pepples
* cocoa almond bliss (smoothie). Housemade almond milk, banana, cocoa, cinnamon, nutmeg, ice.  HEAVEN.
* Ginger "cozy" ... hot water, ginger, lemon, cayenne, and agave. It packs quite a zing!
* apple oatmeal smoothie with agave instead of honey.  Good!
* the avocado smoothie.  thick, and very unusual tasting. I liked it!
* chocolate swirl coffee cake (good)
* vegan and thankfully NOT gluten-free chocolate chip almond butter oatmeal cookie (very good!!!)
* gluten-free chocolate brownies (gluten-free vegan baked goods are not generally good at all, but these had a very nice brownie texture and only a small amount of yucky aftertaste), 
* gluten-free ginger cookie (too crispy, but edible)

I would give it 5 stars, except I don't go there very much now because they have "no-laptop" times now, and I can't remember when those times are.  I go there to get work done, and I don't want to happen to go at the wrong time.  But it has a wonderful atmosphere and a very nice selection of cafe food!  Highly recommended!
author: Rachel D.

description:
Ew, this place is on the sketch side of bernal heights? Where are you taking me??

Fear not, my friend. Cafe St. Jorge is like a sanctuary at the top of the hill.

The fact that this place serves Stumptown coffee is reason enough to make the trek up the hill. If you really need more though, the decor here is what will win any cafe aficionado over. Stumptown cold brew bottles with miniature succulents as table center pieces. What else needs to be said?

(+) the baked egg slider. 
So good. Definitely add the ham and avocado for a fantastic breakfast/ lunch option.

(+) granola bowl.


Pro Tips:
1) They have a bottomless coffee option, but unless you are planning on drinking at least 3 cups, it's probably not worth your while. It comes in a smaller mug than their normal coffee.
2) This CAN be your new study cafe! Amidst the crazy SF rent prices, somehow, a study cafe still exists. Come here! Use your computer! Read a book! Sit for an hour (or two)! No one will judge you.
author: Patricia K.

description: Amazing place we stumbled upon while in SF. Great staff, quaint and cute inside, many food and drink selections offered. Service was friendly and quick. Quality of breakfast and coffee was incredible. Seems very much like the neighborhood place for breakfast. Very busy, but line moves fast and worth the wait. Respect the process and grab your table after you order.
author: Monica J.

description:
This is a nice cafe, but I have to ding them on the sad little grilled ham and cheese they gave me for 8 bucks (after tax). No salad, just a grilled sandwich that looks like it was prepared on hot plate in a dorm room:

http://twitpic.com/e08ddq
author: Ken M.

description: Nice but way too expensive. This is just coffee - people. How many espressos does a pound of coffee make?  $3.35 for an espresso and a drop of milk? $6.50 for a grilled cheese sandwich?? If you value your money, go elsewhere. If you're easily separated from it, they will separate it from you with a smile as they are very nice.
author: Keith R.

description:
This place is the bee's knees! Everything from the decor and color choices to the food and drinks. The service is great- extremely friendly and fast. The food is delicious from the pastries to the grilled sandwiches and not to forget the quinoa bowls! They have a thing for toast and they know what they're doing. If you love avocado, get the avocado and crushed red pepper toast. They also have an avocado smoothie which is pretty serious business.. 

Great place to sit and work on your computer for a few hours, and what's better to do that with then their awesome cheese plate and a glass of wine?! Yes they serve wine and beer (and champagne). 

This place is the honey hive of cafés in the mission and I reccommend it whole heartedly!
author: Zohn M.

description:
All my life's dreams are encapsulated in this cafe.

Healthy selection of food, cute decor, avocados. I had the avocado toast.

By the way... get yourself a dona amelia (pastry).
author: Carleen W.

description: This is becoming our regular sat morning breakfast place. Super casual, pay-first, sit-second format is great. It's a no frills place where you can nosh on delicious Portuguese inspired food. I trusted them and got the Goose is Loose (grilled cheese with ham and banana) and DUDE, it was bomb. BF got the orange blossom waffle, which was very well presented with fruit. We also split the linguisa puff pastry - very good, kinda pricey, would be worth it if it was double the actual size. Cons- my flatware was dirty with food still stuck on, and my coffee for here had remnants of paper or something floating in it. Otherwise amazing.
author: Anita H.

description:
Cafe St. Jorge is a breath of fresh air! A spacious, quaint, and naturally-lit spot in the midst of the Mission, Cafe St. Jorge allows one to take a break from all local taquerias (which are affordable and great - don't get me wrong!). I found this place on Yelp in surprise when in search for a brunch/lunch place nearby. I wasn't sure what to expect, and boy, this visit exceeded my satisfaction!

The decor of this place gives off an air of delicacy and cozy comfort. The blue/black bold yet intricate trimmings/text superimposed against a pure white background is a running theme in the cafe -- seen on their menus, their boards, postcards, etc. The white helps in creating an illusion of an open space, which is perfect for you to work, read, chat etc. Love it. The staff is also incredibly nice and hospitable. 

As for the food -- I came here with two other friends on a Sunday afternoon. We found a table quite easily and went up to order our food. I got the Bimby sandwich, an iced mocha, and a plate of bread and olive oil to share. The Bimby was deliciously well done: the bread was perfectly toasted yet soft enough for your to contour your hands around so the contents don't fall out like a mess. The cheese and tomatoes were super fresh, and the olive oil added a nice touch. The bread was also superbly soft. As for my iced mocha, it was a perfect blend of chocolate and decaf -- both in perfect balance so that not one flavor was too overpowering. In general, there are a sprinkling of options on the menu -- not enough to make you too indecisive -- but just enough to keep you coming back for more! There are also gluten free options too, which is a big plus.

I will definitely come back again next time for Sunday brunch or lunch. Love the atmosphere, food, and the people! What a find! Thanks Yelp!
author: Hurnan V.

description:
Hospitality is what builds loyalty and Cafe St Jorge has definitely made that a priority. It is hard to find a staff that actually smiles and knows how to genuinely be friendly in SF. Especially since Being Disengaged is the new cool. 

I love this place because I can finally eat and drink at an establishment that makes things from scratch! Like their own almond milk, cocoa, juices etc and has plenty of healthy fresh options! I adore places that take that extra time to give their patrons quality food and drinks (without all the extra preservatives and chemicals in them.)

 Great place for light dishes. Sandwich sizes might leave you hungry but they are still delicious.

My favorite items:
Chia Bowl w no agave
Quinoa Bowl w no salt and Brown sugar
Sardine Plate 
Bimby 2.0
Baked Goods
Avocado Chili Toast
Blueberry Ginger smoothie
Almond Bliss smoothie

Not So Great:
-Baked Egg breakfast Sandwich on sourdough (it was mostly bread and a thin barely there layer of Egg Salad) Not much flavor and definitely not filling
-Orange Blossom Waffle. Didnt taste any orange or blossom. Ive had better. 

Even with the two negative orders Ill Still give them a 5 star for staff and everything else on the menu!
author: Gina S.

description:
CAFE WHORE
(4 stars)

I'm such a cafe whore. Do you ever wonder how an individual can sit at a cafe and waste an entire day there? I'm classified as one of them. Its easy, you have to have a deep mind. And quite honestly, for one to adhere such an odd "lifestyle" there has to be good espresso and a welcoming environment. This place has both! 

Great for chit chats 
Great for laptop'ing 
Great for self time 
Great for reading
Great for being a mute 
Great for ipod'ing 
Great for being socially awkward and mute and people starring (lol)

STUMPTOWN COFFEE BEANS!! I kid you not, they have it and it's fabulous. There are three types of beans I adore and STUMPTOWN is one of them. If you don't know about it, silky and smooth is what it's about. No bitter after taste, genuinely a quality bean. 

I have my "cafe days" where I just want to decompress and reflect. It's a comfort thing for me. And I enjoy doing so at random cafés in the city with great espresso. It has to be the Seattle in me, we do this often up there. So, thank you Cafe St Jorge for providing me that atmosphere. 

Will I be back? YUP. 

Until the next review...
author: Jane A.

description:
Full disclosure: I am a picky eater. 

I was introduced to this cafe because a friend gave me half of their hummus sandwich. He told me it was organic and I was all Yassssssss. 

So I went to check it out myself. 

The place is quaint. It has a calming color scheme and is perfect for studying (it already looks like a library upon entering--I think I've seen more macs in this cafe than in a retail apple store). 

The menu is simple but very flavorful. They have coffee--I don't drink coffee so I'm not sure how it is. I know they have dairy-free options for my vegan/dairy allergic friends. 

They make smoothies, I suggest the berry one (it has a ginger kick!), and the oat smoothie is also good for cinnamon lovers. 

They have pastries that were either made in house or locally. They have gluten free and vegan options. 

If you're hungry I recommend the quinoa salad (if you like a salad with personality). 

This is my fave place in this area. Thanks for existing. 

Also, free wifi!!! And succulents on all the tables. Adorable. And and and, they have signs that you can put on your table if you some company--more places should do this.
author: Hospicio Y.

description:
My husband and I went for a lunch with great feeling and hope for new great place to hang out  - we only ordered sandwiches, therefore I can not speak about coffee.
Tosta Mista Sandwich $7.50 I had was burnt on one side of the bread, cheese and ham inside was ok. I added a $2 side salad to my order - wish I have not. It was advertised as fresh lettuce salad - I got everything but fresh on my plate. Leaves in the salad looked old, wilted, lifeless and I'm pretty sure I saw one turned bad already. Chopped carrot on the top wasn't tempting looking either. Overall my lunch was't worth the price I paid.

Wish, my food experience was better. Definitely won't go back - shame because I live near by and interior and service was inviting.
author: Anna S.

description: Super friendly staff. Got a spot outside to sit my pup. Almond cocoa bliss smoothie was SO fresh and so worth the $9. Avocado toast is my favorite. I will get that every time I come. Quinoa salad was a little bland as it was very light in dressing and I love me some dressing.
author: Ashlyn R.

description: Great neighborhood-y cafe with avocado or fruits toasts. Good place to work as well on your Mac :) Not a brunch place but quality food and great place to have coffee and small bites with a friend.
author: Anna S.

description:
Very friendly staff and food was delicious.  Cafe was charming with high ceilings and nice lighting.  
They have fresh green juice!

Unfortunately I didn't find this cafe until right before leaving town, so couldn't visit a second time. 

They do have outlets in the wall, but have signs not to use laptops on weekends, I guess because of crowds and turnover on customers.  

:-)
author: Amber D.

description: Cute coffee shop that's popular but not too popular. I really only stopped by to get the pastel de nata. I picked up a few for myself and a few more to share. Everyone was wowed including me. The custard is thick like creme brulee with a nice caramel top. I love Portugal and wish I could compare but my visit was so long ago. The last time I had these tarts was in Cambridge, UK of all places (also delish). I wish I didn't have to get them to go so I could have them warmed up but I guess that's just an excuse to come back and try out some other things. See you there next week!
author: Jean K.

description: My favorite place to meet friends for delicious coffee and vegan friendly treats. Chia pudding and avocado toast are hefty and satisfying. The baristas work some sort of magic with the non-dairy foam on coffee drinks.
author: Danielle P.

description:
Pro's:
- Fairly fast service
- Good for Californian/Vegetarian style food
- Staff is friendly and attentive

Cons:
- They keep door open so very cold in restaurant
- Music is on the heavy rock style (too music for breakfast)
author: Curtis S.

description: We stopped here while in San Francisco for breakfast. Very cute quaint cafe. The best part was the food! I had an Orange blossom waffle with fruit and a sandwich. Fast service and nice staff. Very much recommended.
author: Brittany R.

description: Absolutely love this place. Lived in sf all my life and never ran into this place. Service was great and the food was awesome. Got to try the waffles! Amazing!
author: Jason J.

description: A fun and yummy place with a great jive. A real San Francisco kind of place. I had the Quinoa bowl. It was huge,incredible and shareable, but everyone was busy with their own plates. My son had the avacado toast. The east is catching up with the avacado craze. Very good, delicious and a perfect portion. Husband was so happy with his food, he rarely poked his head up! It have a very laid back feel, with very friendly staff.
author: Elayne L.

description:
Really good gluten-free bread, almost reminds me of sourdough. I would not say it is worth a visit if it is out of your way but if you live nearby, go try it. Also they have Stumptown Coffee, which is not my fav but decent. I don't normally like hummus very much but I was impressed with the hummus sandwich add avocado. The prices are moderate for the neighborhood, expect to spend $10-$15 on coffee and some toast/sandwich or whatever, and don't bother ordering the side salad it is tiny. 

I have been to Portugal and I can say that it is not a country in which you want to remember the cuisine. Cafe St. Jorge is supposedly Portuguese themed but really it just cute, hipster cafe not offering many Portuguese breakfast foods.
author: Shannon Z.

description: Cool cafe right across the street from where my friend lives. I got the chili avocado toast and almond joy smoothie (house made almond milk, cocoa, banana) for $16. Prices were a bit high but good quality food. The bread for the avocado toast was super thick and tasted home baked. They also give plenty of avocado spread. The smoothie was a bit too sweet with the chocolate but delicious and healthy. It was a good start to my day!
author: Julesy T.

description:
I've never experienced anything quite as frustrating as attempting to get a quick breakfast at this café on a Saturday morning at 9:30.

The items we attempted to order first (ham & cheese pop-tarts) were already gone. Strange, since it was not yet late morning...

We went on to order:
* an iced coffee
* a latte
* a breakfast slider with ham
* a ham & cheese croissant
* a croissant bun
* a bottle of San Pellegrino
- and -
* a chai latte to-go

We were given a number and found a seat. The latte for-here and chai latte to-go were called shortly after that. 

After about 5 minutes, we thought that it was odd that the iced coffee hadn't been called. I waited through the long line once again and was told that there had been an issue but was then promptly provided with an iced coffee.

Then, after waiting about 10 to 15 additional minutes we noticed that even though our food had not yet arrived, everyone who came in after us already had their orders. So then, again, I waited through the quite long line to get back to the register.

I was told that there was some confusion and they had prepared our order to go and had been calling it out - even though they provided us with a number, deliver the food to tables with numbers, and we never heard our order called. But they assured us that the food would be ready shortly since the to-go order they had mistakenly prepared for us had since become cold.

At this point, it had been about an hour.

I decided to leave and my partner stayed and waited another 10 to 15 minutes to get the food that we had paid for over an hour ago. During this period, he noted that multiple orders went out with our exact configuration - meaning they did not prioritize fixing the mistake over other later orders.

The food ended up being quite tasty, but nowhere near enough to justify the ridiculous wait and terrible experience.

All in all, this was a disastrous breakfast excursion that will prevent me from returning and encourage me to inform all of my friends that they should avoid this establishment.
author: Jonathon W.

description: Love this place. It's such a neighborhood staple. Warm atmosphere, lovely interior, great food, great coffee. Everyone else loves it here too; it's always packed!
author: Rebekah C.

description:
Great little neighborhood gem. Serving Stumptown cold brew on tap along with interesting breakfast dishes.

We had the Baked Egg Sliders, Avocado Toast and Coffee, food was delicious, especially the sliders, eggs were fluffy and sweet roll was soft.  Toast was loaded with Avo and olive oil/sea salt, definitely will try again!

Still can't believe I can get Stumptown cold brew (from Portland!) here on tap.  Can't wait to make this Cafe one of my usual haunts!
author: Mykael N.

description: Great food, friendly service.  You should plan on many return visits because there are simply too many wonderful things to sample.
author: Stanley W.

description:
With so many choices for breakfast, San Francisco dares you to become a regular somewhere. Challenge met. I don't write Yelp reviews, but CSJ deserves an exception. This unassuming storefront houses the best pastries, toasts, and morning beverages south of Cesar Chavez. I come here almost every week for their egg custard Pastel de Nata, chili avocado toast, and chai lattes. The music and artwork never disappoint.

In a healthy mood?
- organic chia bowl with fruit
- organic quinoa bowl with fruit
- smoothie with hemp milk
- chili avocado toast

In a nom mood?
- orange blossom waffle with fruit
- pastel de nata (if you remember nothing else)
- apple cinnamon pop tart
author: William M.

description:
Staff was friendly and when I ordered lunch I got my strawberry lemonade right away, and it was the star of my lunch.

We also ordered the cinnamon sugar toast, savory waffle, and the granola.  It took a long time to get our order (about 15 minutes) given that it was a pretty simple one and the place wasn't that busy (mostly just ppl with coffee working on their laptops).

The cinnamon sugar toast was good, the ham on the savory waffle was too salty for my taste, and the yogurt that came w/ the granola was too sour.

All-in-all it was ok; I'd recommend trying Cafe Seventy8 or New Alternatives (which are both nearby).
author: Mike Q.

description:
Laptop camper here. I was a regular at Nervous Dog and was sad to see it close. Café St. Jorge, which took over the space, improved the coffee and the décor - and they kept my old wooden bench and the free wi-fi. They serve Stumptown Coffee. The décor and menu is Portuguese influenced though they also have non-Portuguese food (sandwiches, toast, smoothies, granola, bagels, waffles, etc.) and vegan/gluten free options. They were out of Portuguese pastries during my visit...so I went back and spotted a few Portugeuese cakes and cookies.

* Avocado toast ($5.85): A thick slice of wheat bread with mashed avocado, chili flakes, salt, and olive oil. The toast was hearty. It wasn't toasted long enough and there wasn't much on top of it for a slice of toast that was over $5.
* Portuguese lemon rice cake: Looks like a small muffin, soft slightly crusty top, dense and moist, different texture than the usual muffin, dense and heavy yet moist, bits of lemon rind, more moist in the center, yum 
* Spice cookie ($1.75): a pretty crescent shaped dry cookie, pale on the outside, spiced filling on the inside, soft and interesting, different spices, not super sweet, has a hint of anise
* Latte: made with Stumptown was creamy and smooth, but had no foam art 

The café has a modern blue and white look with ceiling fans, a cluster of old photos, and vintage coffee cans. It's pretty quiet inside though you can hear traffic and I don't like the country music that they play. They have a frequent buyer card for coffee drinks.

You know you love me. X0 X0, laptop camper.
author: Lolia S.

description:
My CoffeeThesisProposal studying has taken me away from Denver and to yet another land.  But coffee shops are coffee shops are coffee shops.

Cafe St. Jorge is delicious.  Over the course of my multi-hour stay, I had a Chia Bowl and a Quinoa Bowl, both of which were completely fantastic.  We just don't have such delicious food in my home territory!  Swoon.

The main downside is holyshit so many people.  I ended up squeezed into a little table with my new best Australian friend, so that we could free up space for others.  There was much scooching through tight spaces to get anywhere, and much bustling about in general.  Blehhhhh.

Grab food and get on with it; don't make a nest for yourself here.
author: Sally P.

description: Excellent selection of food and drink. Full of soul and heart. My celiac-suffering sister of was particularly pleased.
author: Jade P.

description:
This quaint little cafe sits right on Mission and 30th street.  It truly is a hidden gem among the Mission neighborhood and is the perfect place for a Sunday brunch or a catch-up with a friend.  The menu sports different items ranging from salads to sandwichs along with various coffees to try.  Most of all, its affordable and has free wifi!  You order and seat yourself, and the tables are very intimate (usually no bigger than 2-4 people per table.  I was also truly amazed at the artwork along the walls as well, and most of all they provide postcards for you to write!

Treat yourself to a quiet, peaceful cafe meal at Cafe St. Jorge!
author: Robert T.

description: Went for brunch on a saturday. Over priced mediocre food.  $11 for plain kale salad with croutons.  Large waffle topped with likely Costco ham and arugula for $13.  Amateur food that you can prepare at home and shouldn't be served at restaurant for that price point. Lastly it took 30 minutes to get the food.   It seems like a good place for a coffee, pastry but not a proper brunch or lunch place.
author: T D.

description:
I was devastated when Joe closed his Nervous Dog Cafe.  I had hoped he regained his health and opened shop again.  It was not to be.  

Then I saw that a new cafe was going to open soon.  With a Portuguese inspired menu.  The only other Portuguese cafe I knew of was Grubsteak.  With a soft opening at the end of June I set out to try it.  They closed the next week to update and finalize things.  Opening this week, they have a good footing.

I have tried many of the pastries, as well as the coffee.  I have not had time to try the Grilled Cheese or hot entrees.  Every thing has been nothing short of fantastic.  I've had the Kouign Amann, and don't know how to pronounce the "Kouign" so this shall be known as "the Amann thing".  Two specialties are homemade Vegan Banana Nut Bread, and Bolo de Arroz.  I could not tell the banana bread was vegan and was very good.  I have never tried Bolo de Arroz, and this was good as well.  A bit sweet with a hint of lemon.  Don't pass this up!

The coffee by Sumptown Roasters is also very good ... liquid gold!  I usually have coffee at home very early but will have to try to get coffee here more often.  I'm usually on my way to work when I stop by.  

I am looking very much forward to trying more items on the weekend or Thursday / Friday evening when they are open later.  Great staff, and they always have a smile.  Welcome to the neighborhood!
author: Michael M.

description: I'm looking for a place to study and this coffee shop was a a great place. However, I feel guilty for coming in during busy hours so if I do come back. I would avoid the brunch hours. Overall. a nice place to study and I enjoyed the Smoked Salmon Toast.
author: Amy L.

description: Our favorite local breakfast spot. Outstanding avocado toast and pastries. Very unique vibe. Staff is really nice.
author: Ashley K.

description:
fig toast = hella good!
avocado toast = not my cup o coffee!
author: Phuc B.

description:
If you find yourself in the Mission, please don't hesitate to check out this wonderful cafe. 
The staff is always friendly & welcoming.  It is a bit on the smaller side, but they have plenty of tables & if you're in a friendly mood you can put a sign on your table to let people know that they are welcome to share with you.  Very cool.
My go to order here is an iced almond milk latte & avocado toast.  This isn't just any avo toast, people.  It is the biggest piece of toast you've ever laid eyes on, smothered with creamy yet still perfectly chunky avocado, drizzled with olive oil & crushed red pepper flakes.  Come to mama.
author: Jennifer J.

description: Delicious coffee. Wonderful gluten-free and dairy-free options. I enjoyed the Chili Avocado Toast with an egg on top, lattes, and some sort of vegan almond butter-cup-type-thing. The decor is adorable. They have managed to create an environment that is suitable for catching up with friends, working on a laptop, and grabbing takeaway coffee simultaneously.
author: Anne M.

description:
This place was a great find in San Fran for a yummy quick breakfast. A ton of health options and phenomenal nutella hot chocolate. I mean, how can you go wrong with anything with nutella in it??

Try the avocado toast the linguica pastry and of course the nutella hot chocolate. Yum yum and yum!
author: Sabrina M.

description:
Cute little cafe on Mission, the coffee is strong and the food is presented beautifully and tastes wonderful.  
The Pasteis de nata was wonderful, the inside creamy and delicious. My sandwich looked and tasted great. My mother is from the Azores (Pico island) and we all took her here to have coffee and some lunch. While it is different from being in a cafe in the Islands, it is a wonderful place to have a few of the good things in life while being in SF. Parking was easy on the street, and the staff was friendly. 

I would call this a Californian-Azorean cafe. It has some of the good stuff from the bay area (Organic food, Kombucha, salads) and also some little reminders of time in the Islands. (Pasteis da natas, cheeses, and candies) 

I would love to see a patio area here, or something like outside seating, but it was a nice place to find in the City!
author: jen t.

description: This place is an ambiguous one for me. When you come in the afternoon, it's chill. However in the mornings, the experience leaves me preferring Starbucks (Masonic) instead. So I'm sticking to the Latino habit of the mid afternoon coffee.
author: Michael S.

description: As many other reviews say, the Dre Cookie (almond chocolate chip cookie) are amazing and hard not to order every time I come here. The other pastries are also great, the coffee cake slices are massive. The rest of the menu is also killer, the Portuguese baguette and the Chia Bowl are favorites. Finally, Andrea the owner is awesome, which is a bonus!
author: David M.

description: Excellent Portuguese breakfast joint. Hubby and I shared the breakfast slider and the goose is loose. The slider was excellent especially with the ham and avocado addition. The sweet bread was a good contrast to the savory items. The goose is loose was an interesting item. We opted to take off the bananas, and then we decided is was delicious. The coffee was very good and the seating arrangement was pleasant. I recommend to try this place at least once.
author: Lynn E.

description:
Staff is super friendly and Portuguese!  The pastel de Nata are comparable to the original from Belem, Portugal, home of the creation.  (Definitely have it warm for the authentic experience, and true Portuguese eat it without cinnamon or extra sugar on top)

 Quiche was delightful.  Great cappuccino and coffee!  Overall great, we will be back!
author: Michele B.

description: One of my favorite places for brunch! I always get their iced vanilla latte, which is always perfect with right amount of vanilla syrup and milk. Chilli Avocado Toast and Almond Butter with Banana and Honey toast are my favorite. I usually go here on weekdays because weekends can get pretty packed. They have free wifi so it's a good place to sit down and study too if you want.
author: Jasmine Y.

description: Disappointing. Had heard about fresh baked goods at cafe so we tried it. Unfortunately, we were greeted with poor customer service from the start.  Employees were horsing around when we approached the counter and seemed unconcerned by me as a customer.  Items over priced to start with (6.75 breakfast sandwich) and then price add-ons to menu items piled on. Water for tea was served luke warm. When I asked for some boiling water, the counter person's excuse "that's as hot as our machine can get it" was symbolic of the apathy of the business. Food wasn't bad but for the price and lack of welcome shown its not worth it. Don't waste your time.
author: Jon R.

description: By far my favorite mocha and yes I am a coffee addict. It has a good balance of chocolate and coffee flavor without being too sweet. The Portuguese tart was delicious also. I've been to Macau where Portuguese tart was very famous and I will say this place has one that can compete. Highly recommended this place, but be aware of long lines during weekends.
author: Crystal W.

description:
Finally, a seriously strong latte in the neighborhood! Plus the friendly staff, the clean/ cute logo and cafe set up, healthy and delish smoothies what's not to love?! 
I'm looking forward to trying their food menu soon.
author: Jennifer D.

description: Great place for weekend brunch! Coffee is amazing (Stumpton), some of the best in SF. The food is delicious and very reasonably priced. The cafe was a little under staffed leading to some delays which is why four instead of five stars. Will definitely be back.
author: K M.

description: After stopping by at Pinhole for a coffee, I made a quick stop off at Cafe St. Jorge since I was DYING for something to eat.  While I could have had a pastry at Pinhole, something about what they had didn't appeal to me.  Oddly enough, when I walked into Cafe St. Jorge, EVERYTHING appealed to me.  Since I was in sort of a rush, I had to go with what was in the pastry case.  I opted for the Pasteis de Nata based on Yelp's suggestion, and also the Dona Amelias which is basically a sweet corn muffin (advertised as gluten free!).  While the Pasteis de Nata wasn't warm, I thought it was delicious.  But, the real treat was that Dona Amelias.  I keep hearing about these amazing bowls that are served at Cafe St. Jorge, so I will most definitely return back here if I'm in the area again to have one when time allows me to.  I love the Portugese inspired menu, it's definitely unique and something that I'll remember!
author: Lisa I.

description:
Love the sign, the mugs, the decor, the staff!! Even love that they have some of the menu items written in Portuguese (like galao). 

I had a lovely time here having a cup of coffee and baguette with olive oil. The olive oil was great, with a sprinkle of salt layered on the bottom of the oil. 

I also tried the Pasteis de Nata (eggtart), which I'm a HUGE fan ever since I tried the actual pasteis from Belem, Portugal. I was a little disappointed when the nata came out a little too soft, instead of crunchier on the outside. I think it might be because they (kindly :) ) heated it up for me, so maybe next time I'll just ask to get it right off the counter. Also, try to get it without any cinnamon - for the 'real' portuguese experience. 

Great atmosphere, and truly lovely interior. I heard from the staff that the owner is from Azores, Portugal. I'm glad she/he opened such a cafe. Satisfied my craving for Portuguese everything :). Will return, for breakfast or lunch - and next time, I'm getting myself some galao!
author: Soo Jung R.

description: We love Cafe St Jorge and would give it 5 stars except that the prices are a bit high. The ambiance is lovely, the coffee is great, and the food is super delicious, with many healthy options, including vegetarian and vegan options. It can be extremely crowded on weekends with a long wait for a table. They also have nice merchandise, including local ceramics, clothing, and Portuguese delicacies. It closes on 6pm on weekdays; I wish it were open later so I could go there after work.
author: Eve A.

description: Everything about this places vibes with me from the atmosphere, to the stumptown coffee, to their delicious gluten free breakfast sliders. I used to live in Bernal Heights and was a regular here. Now I live in the peninsula and will sometimes made a deliberate trip up to the city just so that I can visit this place!
author: Clair D.

description:
The house-made granola is so tasty! The fava bean crostini is amazing! 

This is a great spot for breakfast or brunch for 2-4. Not a good spot for large groups. 

The Stumptown coffee is well made and so rich. Coffee lovers, you will not be disappointed. 

Order up at the register, get a table number, sit down, and your food will be delivered to your table .
author: T N.

description: Love this place! Super cute inside and amazing kale caesar salad. The benches are a little low for working on a laptop, but they have plenty of outlets.
author: Lindsay L.

description: Loved the fig toast and avocado toast. Def will come back to try all the other options. They are very filling and delicious for breakfast.
author: Sandra S.

description: I came here with a friend for the first time the other day and the first thing I noticed was the layout! It was very at home. However, it seemed so cramped and small that it made the room really hot and standing in line was a pain. The register and pickup area was right next to each other in one small corner so everyone was always trying to get past one another. It didn't make it better when the sugar and creamer table was also right next to the pick up station. Basically, everything was in one small corner! It made everywhere hard to get to! Overall, my drink was good, but not the best. It would have made my visit better if they managed their place layout a bit more!
author: Emily S.

description:
I really wanted to like this Cafe after hearing awesome things. Unfortunately, my first visit wasn't really that great. There was very limited seating, and the line took forever. I've worked a cash register before and there is really no reason it should take 20 minutes to take 3 orders...

I wanted a fruit salad and a cup of tea. Any other place in the world this would be a very affordable breakfast. The cashier asks me for $10.85. I was really confused. "Ohhhh you wanted a fruit CUP not a fruit BOWL." Cup of tea was still $3. 

I plan on trying Cafe St. Jorge again. Hopefully I can re-review and give a better rating!
author: Jasmine M.

description: I go here whenever I'm visiting my sister in Bernal Heights--it's definitely worth the climb back up. Their coffee is the best I've ever tasted, their toasts are really generous for the price, and anything involving the Portuguese ham and cheese is so delicious.
author: V W.

description:
it is so cute here. came here this morning with my friend to try something healthy for breakfast. got a chia bowl, avocado toast, and a baked egg sandwhich. it was all pretty good. knocked down 1 star because it felt like forever for the food to come out.. like 25 minutes.....

the latte with almond milk was good as well.

overall, a fan.
author: Catherine Y.

description: Great local spot, lovely workers, good coffee! The Avocado toast is amazing! A great spot for vegans and vegetarians also, since they have some great menu options for everybody.
author: Lana V.

description:
Cafe St. Jorge is delicious. Eat the almond butter toast. Drink Coffee. 

But, don't take up a large table with your laptop and notes. Go work somewhere else. You're killing the vibe.
author: Brian J.

description:
I love their coffee, always just right!

I found this place when i lived in Bernal, and i still come here to work and have quiet time. try their menu, food is good but the prices go up as SF gets more expensive.

In this case the prices are reasonable and worth it!
they also have a punch card so i can get a freebie once in a while, and free wifi!



you know what, don't come..
author: I A.

description:
This place was such a wonderful find. Cool breakfast/brunch/cafe Portuguese-inspired food, and tasty as hell.

We had the avocado toast, the special toast of the day which included date jam topped with figs and honey, and the kale salad (zomg, that lemon vinaigrette). Coffee was also solid.

Everything was super fresh, staff was really nice, and we sat in the window and got to people watch. 

The good: delicious food.
The bad: alternate name for Cafe St. Jorge could be "Cafe All The MacBook Pros."
author: Amanda B.

description: Food is amazing.  Quinoa bowl and the slider was unbelievable.  Would go back in a heart beat.
author: Justin R.

description: First, I'd like to say that we have been loyal customers of this establishment since the day it opened! We frequent this cafe twice a week Mondays and Fridays. This was one of our favorite spots in the Mission. I'm so sorry to say that the employees are treating people differently if they have children. Two weeks in a row we (my son and I ) have been treated differently as smiles are hand out to persons in front of us and behinds us in line ( last week with Kylie ). Today the counter gal (Alexia) lashed out at my son for playing with the business cards in front of the register. I explained that if an employee has a problem with a child you should address it with the parent. It was inappropriate behavior by a cafe clerk to reprimand anyones child. Especially a small nonverbal, special needs child that lacks in confidence and has anxiety issues. I am even more furious that the general manager Kevin made excuses as to the behavior of his staff and why the employee lashed out, writing it off as the employees having frustration with all the kids that come in that drop and break things and "cause damages" his words. My son touches the business cards and the tiny little scale that goes up and down in front of the register. Hardly the same as "damages". Only excuses were provided no one apologized for their action toward my child, or how we have been treated. BEWARE PEOPLE - children are not liked here by the current staff. I want to be clear here to this young staff at Cafe St Jorge that discrimination base on age, disabilities, etc.., toward any one person or group is unlawful ! Not only should you treat everyone equally, but working in a service based industry where you encounter customers face to face you put on your best and friendliest face everyday and use your good manners, please, thank you and I'm  sorry ! If I see one more face that looks at us with disgust and you treat us differently then the other customers as has happened the last two weeks because of my child ( special needs ) I will contact Disabilities Rights California and file a complaint with their Attorneys.
author: Margareta M.

description:
Good Stumptown coffee and a nice comfortable environment to work or chat. Food was overpriced and underwhelming, but I would come again to try their toast and pastries or have a coffee and work.

We stopped by on a lazy Sunday morning for breakfast and work; the cafe was busy but not crowded. The space was pleasant for working, not too loud, with free wifi and plug-in space underneath the benches. The decor had a decidedly Portugese flare to it, but this didn't seem to come out too much in the food.

Our breakfast was a chia bowl and a toasta mista. The bowl had a nice assortment of fresh fruit and was delightfully cinnamon-y, but ultimately nothing extraordinary. The toasta mista was pretty good, but seemed little more than an expensive grilled ham and cheese sandwhich. 

The drip coffee was delicious, of course (of course, Stumptown) but a little old by the time they served it. My espresso shot was surprisngly well-made, though.
author: Daniel P.

description: This place changes lives. I had the green smoothie and baked egg breakfast slider. Talk about food porn. Their baked egg sandwich has sriracha butter that soothes the soul. Two words: sriracha butter. Their avo toast is also amazing. Stole a bite from my boyfriend then ended up eating half while he was in the bathroom. Girlfriend of the year, I know.
author: Theresa S.

description: Great place. Recommend anyone to stop by.  The avocado chili toast is amazing. (Not pictured here). The Gingibre was very well made sweet then a kick of spice.
author: Daniel L.

description: There are many impressive things about this place: smoothies made with avocado and almonds; Portuguese style plates (or boards), a vegan waffle that isn't too bad. But the thing that most impressed me is the book exchange. A small ice box next to the door bears a sign: Take a book Leave a book. Within is found a truly impressive collection of literature which speaks to the quality of patrons who frequent this place. I think I could live in this neighborhood. :)
author: Janean P.

description: Best DAMN cappuccino in TOWN! Good service and awesome artwork from local artist that frequently changes on the walls.
author: Sia M.

description: Cute small cafe that serves pretty good food. I walked in and found this place pretty packed with hipsters working away on their trusty laptops, so obviously they have WiFi! I tried the avocado toast and it's pretty good. I also tried the avocado smoothie and not sure about the taste but let's just say it's interesting. I would definitely come back and check out their breakfast items. Parking is tough as its only street parking in the Mission.
author: Ny H.

description:
I come here for the amazing fig toast and their Stumptown coffee.

What's delightful as well is they display art from local artists for sale on the walls, so patrons are constantly surrounded by awesome art. 

It seems that I will be a constant here, it's a great place to get some work done on your laptop during non-busy hours. Employees are great and music is great. Love Cafe St. Jorge!
author: Rachel T.

description:
Darling new cafe. Color scheme and decor of the interior is carried out well, and has a rustic, yet modern earthy feel. Succulents on the table? how cute!
Prices are on the higher side, but atmosphere and quality are great. Between Stumptown coffees and an assortment of healthy & refreshing juices/smoothies, there is something for everyone!
author: Tuwie N.

description:
Love this place and am so excited to have a cafe in the neighborhood again!
I have been several times so far and love their coffee drinks and really love that they offer almond milk and Stump Town coffee!
Portuguese pastries are delicious!
Juices, salads and little munchies (olives) are all wonderful.
Service is great and I don't feel rushed when deciding to work or hang out here.
Free wifi, a great amount of two tops so if you come to work or meet someone you are not at a shared large table with people you don't know which is awesome.
author: Katie S.

description: Favorite coffee shop in the area. Only bad thing about reviewing this place means more people are likely to go. Best place to work out of during the week with really good internet connection and bottomless coffees. Also, extra points for their choice in music and unique branding. The staff is also really nice--the owner does a good job. Make sure to leave tips, they work hard and deserve them!
author: Sheryl W.

description:
I love LOVE cafe st. jorge. My coworker orders their cookies frequently and they are always delicious. My favorite thing we've had is mint chocolate chip cookies. 

The actual cafe is really inviting and the staff is always very nice. If I were the kind of person that did work in cafes, I think this would be a good one.
author: Julia D.

description:
great staff and good eats
great for working remotely (stable and quick internet connectivity)
their mugs are awesome
they serve beer and chia bowls
the staff are so friendly
author: Joseph V.

description:
My favorite local coffee shop. Lots of heart, minimal pretension. Cozy decor.

Andrea, the owner, is an absolute gem. She once insisted on pulling five espressos for me because the machine was acting up and she wanted my drink to be perfect. The end result was easily one of the best espressos I've ever had.
author: Andrew C.

description: Wow, delicious and wonderful atmosphere. I was on a quest for Pastel de Nata and found theirs to be so delicious and authentic. The taste took me back to Lisbon, Portugal and that's how I wanted to feel. It's not just a place to grab a meal or a coffee, it's a place that transported you straight to Portugal. Love this place and the staff there is incredible. They deserve 10 stars!
author: Jeremy D.

description: I really appreciated all the vegan options. Very cute cafe ambiance with lots of salads, baked goods, coffee options, etc
author: Sky B.

description:
I love getting served Decaf when I ask for a regular.  Only if it's served by a hipster D Bag.  

That's why I order a large coffee, to be all tired and groggy.  

GM or owner is hot though, hence the 2nd star.
author: Rod T.

description: Kind of bougie. Food is pretty okay but not a lunch spot. This is more of a coffee shop so don't expect a serious bite.
author: Peter S.

description: They have great breakfast options. The chia and quinoa bowls are a great protein/fiber rich alternative to typical breakfast options. Though, if you're looking for a tasty treat, they have plenty of Portuguese baked goods to keep your palette busy.
author: Anton S.

description: Excellent vegan options for breakfast. Tried the chia bowl with granola and orange blossom waffle with fruit. The avocado was also excellent.
author: Josh B.

description:
I love Cafe St. Jorge, the staff is nice, the Java is great and like the selection of pastries...the Wi-Fi also comes in handy.  It's kid friendly and feels very welcoming.
If I was to have a coffee shop, I'd like it to be like Cafe St. Jorge.
author: Fatima S.

description: The cafe is lovely and isn't overly crowded. The neighborhood still has the Mission flavor with a mix of locals and newbies that live in harmony. Bright and welcoming, you feel like you're hanging out at a spot near a beach with the sweet decor. The best part is that they serve Stumptown coffee, which means I don't have to travel Portland to get my fix.
author: Theresa D.

description: This review is only for the Portuguese tarts. I read an article about them in a magazine and decided to try it. I've had portuguese tarts from Macau and they were amazing! I was looking forward to the same. So bummed! $10 later my friend and I wish we didn't waste our money. They were tiny for $2.50 each, half the size of a normal portuguese tart. Maybe because they have been sitting out, they were soggy crusted and cold thick dense center with not alot of flavor. No bueno!! It's supposed to have a flaky crispy crust with a light creamy middle.
author: Karen T.

description:
REALLY spicy chai that is not for the faint of heart (this is awesome - the gingery flavor in combination with the spices is enough to get rid of the WORST cold and remind a brown person of their parents' concoctions when they were children). 

great cookies which i expected to disappoint but were really soft. nice ambiance, not too packed, and ample outlets. 

ill be back.
author: Siva M.

description:
Came to SF by way of Arizona. My girlfriend's family is from St. Jorge in the Azores so we thought this would be a good place to check out as the cafe is a tribute to the area. 

We ordered a Blueberry Ginger smoothie which was delicious and a Especie pastry which was also tasty. We bought a cool Cafe St. Jorge mug and the lady helping us seemed to be very polite and helpful. They sell Bread SRSLY which is a local gluten-free sourdough bread, big plus! Lazy traveler I am on my last day in town, I had bought an old loaf without checking it - the owner of the cafe and the bread company were both really cool about it and refunded me no problem. Thank you!

I would recommend this cafe and it's products. Good ambience and service, tasty food and drink, and I'm sure a good American tribute to St. Jorge and the Azores.
author: Carson C.

description: Cute cute cute! We were in the area looking for a coffee shop to do some work so we relied on yelp and found this little gem. It's located in a very interesting neighborhood and from the outside of the street, I almost didn't want to go in but once we walked up to the sign for this cafe, I was instantly charmed. I just came back from a trip to Lisbon and the styling and decor of the cafe reminded me of the Lisbon charm. Aquatic, sardines, and just general casual mediterranean. They served sight glass my favorite coffee and also had homemade coffee bread. This place is not very close or convenient to me in SOMA but if I am in the area I would totally come back for a visit!
author: Betty C.

description:
I had to write again just because their vegan coffee cake (I had something like, banana flambe inspired?) is freaking amazing, and they give you a huge slab, making it economical as well.

This place continues to be my favorite spot for bottomless coffee and a vegan snack, though the secret is out and the tables are almost always packed on a weekend now.
author: Tamara F.

description:
We recently went here to work from a cafe on a typical sunday. 
We drove to the cafe and  were able to find parking easily. The Cafe itself has around 17 tables, there are always a few open. One huge added plus is there are ALOT of Plugs. The food: 
* Quinoa Bowl - Great
* Chia Bowl - Great
* Avocado Chilli toast - Super Filling

Coffee: This certainly is not a Philz but if your just looking for the basics they have them covered.
author: Cameron M.

description:
The coffee menu is pretty standard. (Bottomless coffee is only $4!) I ordered the chai coffee cake and asked for it to be warmed but the center was still cold. I guess the worker was worried I'd burn myself, but I'd prefer that the center was at least more than room temperature! There wasn't a lot of chai flavor either. It was definitely spiced but not with the traditional chai flavors like ginger, cardamom, or cinnamon. 

The thing that bothered me the most and disrupted my studying was one of the workers in the back. There were two workers chatting in the back (which is fine since this isn't a library), but I was really annoyed by how LOUD she was and that she kept gossiping and swearing about other people. I was seated by the door and they were behind the counter in the kitchen area (maybe 30-40 feet away).  It just disrupted the relaxing vibe of the cafe. I'll have to bring headphones next time!
author: Denise C.

description: Awesome brunch spot! We had the avocado toast, the fig toast special which included date jam topped with figs and honey, and the chia bowl. Our favorite was the fig toast special. It was amazing and unlike anything I have eaten before. We also loved the avocado toast and chia bowl. All items were perfect for sharing and I loved the vibe of this place.
author: Wayne H.

description:
DO NOT get the orange juice here!!

I was in the mood for fresh squeezed OJ, and happened to be stopping by Cafe St. Jorge with a friend. OJ is $4.25, so I ordered one thinking I was getting a fresh squeezed juice.

Dead wrong. I cringed as I watched the guy pour my OJ from a Califia Farm bottle. Into a tiny (12oz or so?) plastic cup.

Afterwards, I wept as I found out Whole Foods had *the same* orange juice for sale for $3.99, and you get much more juice.

It also wasn't very good - tasted like pretty generic bottled orange juice. Blech! I felt cheated all around.

Go elsewhere if you're going for orange juice.

(+1 star because they have Stumptown. Whatevs, I still hate being so blatantly ripped off.)
author: Chris M.

description:
The vibe of this cafe is perfectly suited for getting work done with some seriously delicious gluten free/vegan pastries. 

I love that it's low key, not too crowded or loud and the staff is very friendly.

Pastry favorites:
- Gluten free vegan chocolate chip cookie - Small in size but makes up for it in taste.  I think all chocolate chip cookies should have this richness and balance of sweet and salty. If all vegan food was this good I would convert on the spot.

- Cinnamon sugar toast -  Imagine giant cinnamon toast crunch taste in soft buttery form. Amazed that a single slice of bread could be so delicious.
author: Audrey N.

description:
As a San Francisco newbie, I decided to get a jumpstart on finding my favorite cafes and restaurants in my new neighborhood. Cafe St. Jorge came up in the top coffee shops in my area, and I headed right over. I was delighted to find out that my iced tea order came with unlimited free refills! With my drink, I ordered a grilled cheese and salad. It was a bit pricey, but was incredibly delicious. 

Fortunately for those of us who work remotely, the cafe has speedy wifi and plenty of seats to get work done in a pleasant atmosphere. I will definitely be frequenting Cafe St. Jorge at least four times a week!
author: Sasha B.

description: We discovered Cafe St. Jorge simply passing by and were drawn in by the displayed coffee all day sign.  We order the avocado smoothie (delicious), granola bowl, and toast. Everything was made of quality and really good.  If you love Chia bowls and Jeff Goldblum this is your place.....
author: Micaela G.

description:
When I learned that there was a coffee shop a half block away from where I moved I was pretty happy. When I learned they use Stumptown beans, I was estatic. 

Moving from Portland recently I thought I would never have the wonder that is Stumptown roasters on a regular basis again. That is until I found Cafe Jorge and all it has to offer.

The handmade treats are fantastic. Too fantastic. 

The employees and owners are wonderful to deal with and make it a worthwhile "regular" joint. 

If you're south of Chavez on Mission, look nowhere else for your sweet treat/coffee fix.
author: Anthony G.

description: Food is good here. Atmosphere is super cute. I love coming here in the morning bc it's right under my building. Lots of sunlight, good coffee, but may be a bit cramped when the hour is popular (weekend brunch especially).
author: Wei W.

description:
I was aimlessly wandering down the street and ended up here. Such a gem compared to most of the other things on this street, inside and out! 
A very cute environment, a fun menu and a very cute/great staff. 
Highly recommended, especially if you aren't from the area and want to go somewhere low key :)
author: Natalie M.

description: Really adorable cafe - really reminds me of a cute spot in Lisbon. The food is delicious and there are a lot of healthy options! We ordered the granola with almond milk & the cinnamon toast. Both were delicious. The green juice is also really good!
author: Jillian P.

description: This is a nice little breakfast/coffee place in the southern part of the Mission. The coffee is Stumptown, so you know it's good. There is an extensive selection of vegetarian and gluten free options, and all items are labeled whether they fall in one of those two categories (or both). The custard tarts are really good, almost as good as in Macau. The homemade granola is also quite tasty, try it with fruit and yogurt.
author: Brian S.

description: Good coffee, nice pastel de nata, but crap-tasting coconut pastry. Reaction to my complaining about the coconut pastry: basically,  "oops, I guess you're just sh*t-out-of-luck". Won't be coming here again.
author: Hans-Peter G.

description:
The decor is adorable and the vibe is great! Oh and may I add that the staff is extremely friendly, which is rare to find in sf cafes! 
 

If you like strong lattes, then this is the place for you! They don't joke around! :)
author: Nathalie B.

description: high quality food + coffee (Stumptown done right). I got the thick date cream cheese + honey + figs (big & fresh) toast. So much healthy over the top goodness - we were done halfway through!
author: Diane B.

description:
The place it's really charming and comfy and the food it's delicious. I had the sandwich The Goose is Loose (w/ bananas) and it was sooo good! I will recommend to my friends, for sure.

PS:everybody from the staff was really nice as well.
author: Camila F.

description:
I love it when cute, hip cafes serving good quality coffee (Stumptown) and conscious food pop up in the "not-so-hip" parts of Mission Street.  We need these little gems in the more affordable and more humble areas of SF (which are dwindling fast, might I add).
Great ambiance with nice tables for sitting, reading, studying, munching and sipping.  And the music is not overwhelming or loud.  I'm comparing it the the disappointment called "Tierra Mia" that took over my favorite little cafe down the street.  Cafe St. Jorge will be my new go-to.
author: Avi S.

description:
Finally! A specialty coffee place in our neighborhood. They brew Stumptown (as of this posting), and they do it well. Pastries are good--gluten-free options, vegan options. The owner is friendly and welcoming. Music wasn't obnoxious like it can be at some specialty coffee shops. And wifi! 

Also, smoothies, teas, cold drinks... but I didn't try any of those.
author: Chris B.

description:
Welcome to the neighborhood, Andrea! Although I was sad to hear that Nervous Dog had closed down, I realized I'd only visited once or twice since moving to the neighborhood 3 years ago.

Today, I stopped by to check out the new tenants. I'd been following along on Cafe St. Jorge's progress via their Kickstarter page and a few food blogs, and was happy to hear they'd finally opened. The space is sunny and casually minimal - there's free wifi and plenty of tables to snack and work. I ordered the housemade almond milk drink - it's pricey ($8.50) but delicious - a good occasional treat. The owner, Andrea, is friendly and welcoming, and she's serious about the Portuguese angle - she's got bins of imported Portuguese olive oil for sale and in use in the kitchen. Can't wait to come back and try the toast selection (this may be my new Mill alternative), the vegan snacks, and the coffee!
author: Connie H.

description:
I don't typically write reviews, but Cafe St. Jorge has blown my socks off. Seriously, this is the real deal, and deserves all the love it can get.

Pros: excellent coffee, extremely tasty baked goods, everything I've ordered off the food menu has been good, lots of seating, it's an awesome place to relax with a book OR to be super productive, and the staff is awesome.

Cons: It's only been open 1 month and based on my experiences so far, I expect it's going to be crowded very soon.
author: Dillon C.

description: Coffee done right... And with the Portuguese accompaniments, it makes this one of a kind cafe a SF favorite. With easy parking and Wifi it's easy to enjoy your artistically crafted drink or treat. Great staff, great regulars and the owner knows what she's doing!
author: Carlo D.

description:
Love the atmosphere of this place. The bottomless coffee is a very welcoming thing. It says please, stay a while! There was a great mix of single folks and groups. People chatting and others on their laptops. It is definitely a busy place with locals, but everyone seemed to find a spot. 

I popped in today because I wanted to try a new place and sit a while. I also dithered around at home so breakfast was necessary! 

The breakfast portion of the menu was smaller than expected but the breakfast sandwich was great. I wasn't sure how the sweet roll would work, but it was perfect. Prices are a little high, but the quality was there so I won't complain (well, too much, I'm cheap sometimes!). 

Most importantly (to me) the drip coffee was great but not pretentious!
author: Angel G.

description: Very cool neighborhoody space. My Chia bowl was great! Gets crowded on the weekends but overall young people reading, chatting, on their computers etc . It was a nice atmosphere. I enjoyed my experience.
author: C A.

description: SO glad Cafe St. Jorge has joined the neighborhood. I live about a block away and couldn't be happier with a new place to haunt. Delicious but unpretentious coffee (Stumptown)? Check. Amazing healthy breakfast options (chia bowl, smoothies, juices)? Check. Colossal hunks of toast coated in various sweet and savory toppings? Check. Amazing housemade almond milk? Check? Adorable mugs, postcards, decor? Check. Friendly service? Check check check. Decent prices? Chizzitycheck. Fun blend of Portugal and San Francisco? Check. Do you get it yet?
author: Elena K.

description: Fuck that, 6.25 for a mediocre smoothie that I finished in 2 minutes? Even if anything in this place tastes good its a huge ripoff. Go elsewhere.
author: Sarah G.

description:
Myself and two friends went in one Tuesday afternoon for a coffee, there was only one table free at the door, we had 3 babies one of which was asleep in a stroller. Every other table that seated 4 had one person at each table. We were approached by a blonde staff member who told us to move the stroller - God knows where she expected us to put it!! I explained to her that there was a baby sleeping in it and her reply was, in an extremely rude tone, "well do something about it" 

1) The stroller was NOT blocking anyone form entering or exiting the cafe.

2) Had she any bit of cop-on she would have gone to one of the larger tables that seated 4, and is more out of the way, an asked that one person sitting at it to swap with us! but, no, she prefer the rude approach.

This woman was so rude to us that we and none of our other friends will EVER go to this cafe again!! This was a really stupid move by her considering that Mothers on maternity leave have loads of time to go drink coffee's and eat brunch!! So they have lost a lot of custom because of her!!
author: Gail S.

description: They've got something good going here.  The food and treats are amazing.  The coffee is perfect every time.  I'm a big fan of Philz coffee so I'm critical of other coffee based on that standard.  CSJ's Stumptown dark roast exceeds the standard...  it's delicious, I could enjoy it every day, and I do try to. The people who work here and visit here are nice and friendly (I love being asked about me, being called "hun"), and the atmosphere is "cute", clean and airy.  Great little gem in the Mission.  Love this place!
author: Bobby G.

description:
Fruitify.

Impressive audio: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=se1c-UTbPS4

Impressive edibles: Excellent smoothie with apple, organic oatmeal, nonfat milk cinnamon and honey plus a delicious thick slice of wheat toast with sage berry jam.

Lacking fruit but just as good were the surprisingly smooth quad shot Americano and oatmeal, almond butter and chocolate chip cookie.

Awesome staff and space remain the same from my first visit.

Suncatcher rarely disappoints. Same can now be said for Cafe St. Jorge.
author: Jason B.

description:
This place is run by a team of efficient and sweet people. Good food options (and freshly baked goodies!), absolutely awesome Stumptown coffee, and good internet connection. It's a great place to work at or to hang out with friends. Try their avocado chilli toast - so interesting! 

These guys are one of the VERY few coffee shops in the area to provide good internet. Most coffee shops in the area, with the exception of Haus, have turned their internet off to "encourage conversations."
author: N B.

description: The only thing that I don't like about this place is that they don't allow laptops on weekends. It just doesn't make sense to me.
author: Lamia A.

description: If you're in the Mission, drop into this cafe for a special meal. I had the Stumptown coffee and the Chia bowl. Yum! A variety of toasts are offered here as well as many GF offerings. Free wifi, clean bathroom and smiling faces. What more could you want?!
author: Mary B.

description:
Just tried the new Cafe St. Jorge at Mission & Kingston (the space formerly known as The Nervous Dog).  My first experience was great - the coffee (from stumptown roasters) was perfect (I had a mocha - just right not too sweet, nicely balanced). I also had their "Tosta Mista" which is a Portuguese-style grilled cheese sandwich with ham.  This was stellar - slightly smokey, crunchy and melty.  They have a nice mix of savory and sweet things on the menu (with both real breakfast & lunch items).

The space is open and uncluttered, the decor is light and airy; the staff is very friendly.  

I think I have found my new go-to coffee-shop in Bernal.
author: David S.

description: Love the vibe.  Friendly staff.  The food is super dooper. We have fun everytime we go!
author: Flynn S.

description:
Open airy atmosphere. 

Great coffee. 

Bought into some Toast because I was very hungry.  Got a surprised look when I ordered two pieces
 "...you must be hungry!" said the owner

Both pieces were substantial in size, but the best part, they were overfull with toppings.  

Basically the Avocado and chili flake toast was quite delicious.  

I will definitely be back especially for some homemade baked goods.  

(The only negative thing I have to write is that the stretch of Mission street leading to Cafe St. Jorge is quite terrible for biking.)
author: Artnok A.

description: It was quite nice. Breakfast slider with avocado and ham was winner out of our selections (even though it sounded boring to me, personally). Followed by the savory waffle (I think that's what it was called) then the loose goose (which I expected to come out on top). Loose goose was tasty but too rich for your primary meal. I would recommend sharing it and getting another entree. Staff was friendly as well. A little pricey though. Three coffees and three (smallish) entrees totaled forty bucks.
author: Lindsay T.

description: Casual eatery where you order at the counter and get a number.  They bring you the food and then you bus your own table.  So my expectations were not that high.  However, the presentation and taste of the food blew me away.  The food is Instagram-worthy, which is probably why the food took a while to get to me.  Gets crowded in the mornings with lots of kids.
author: somel y.

description:
Excited to see something open up in this space.  Since I walk this way most days

Nervous Dog had ok coffee, this place has amazing mouth liquid!  To my primary facehole the latte they served me this AM was on par with anything out of Four Barrel/Ritual/Blue Bottle/Sightglass/asorted other fanci coffehaus.

Welcome to the hood peeps, hope you stick around!
author: steve a.

description: This place is lovely. We ordered a ton of food - we were very hungry! We ordered the sandwich special (figs, prosciutto, Portuguese cheese, arugula, honey, etc. all on a Portuguese sweet roll) ---- mmmm, our greatest decision, the Reyes salad & hummus plate (both delicious), a juice with ginger & cayenne (amazing), an awesome smoothie, Stumptown coffee, and more! Oh and the baked goods were to die for...The staff was very friendly- they even offered my daughter a high chair and a children's book to keep her occupied! The ambiance was perfect. Easy (meter) parking. We will definitely be back!
author: Kelly F.

description: Had the avocado chili toast and the cocoa almond bliss. Both tasted fantastic. It's a great place to stop by and get a quick bite. Seemed like a nice place to get some work done as well. Felt like a good combination of a coffee shop with different & good food.
author: Karim J.

description: Welcome to the Nervous Jorge haha. We call it that since it was formerly the Nervous Dog coffee shop. This place is great for coffee and tasty healthy snacks. Uses local breads and pastries. I like it, so far a great success. Doing much better than the other recently opened coffee shop here in Bernal, Tia Mare which refuses to give customers wifi hah. Less pretentious than the look of Tia. Cafe St. Jorge always has people there whereas other place is empty.
author: Silicon W.
